Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
Project Number: 52011-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
February 2019 
 
 
Implementing the Integrated Trade Agenda in the 
Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
Program 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
  CCC  –  Customs Cooperation Committee 
  CITA  –  CAREC Integrated Trade Agenda 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  RSAP  –  rolling strategic action plan 
  RTG  –  Regional Trade Group 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TFA  –  Trade Facilitation Agreement 
  WTO  –  World Trade Organization 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  Stephen Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  Amy Leung, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  Ying Qian, Public Management, Financial Sector, and Regional 
Cooperation Division, EARD 
   
Team leader  Dorothea Lazaro, Regional Cooperation Specialist, EARD 
Team members  Desi Arvin Diaz, Associate Project Analyst, EARD 
  Consuelo Javier, Project Analyst, EARD 
Rosalind McKenzie, Senior Regional Cooperation Specialist, EARD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help implement the Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Integrated Trade Agenda (CITA) 2030, which was 
endorsed at the 17th CAREC Ministerial Conference in November 2018.1 Under the framework 
of the CAREC 2030 strategy,2 the CAREC Program aims to strengthen its role as a catalyst for 
trade  expansion  and  economic  diversification  to  enhance  the  growth  potential  of  CAREC 
countries and improve people’s living standards. Such direction reinforces the pivotal role of trade 
as a means of implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.3 
 
2.  CITA 2030 aims to help CAREC members integrate further into the global economy 
through trade expansion from increased market access, greater diversification, and stronger trade 
institutions. The TA is aligned with the Asian Development Bank (ADB)’s (i) Strategy 2030 
operational priority on regional cooperation and integration;4 and (ii) Operational Plan for Regional 
Cooperation  and  Integration,  2016–2020,  specifically,  operational  direction  2  on  raising 
competitiveness in connected markets.5 The TA activities include policy advice, research, and 
capacity building identified in CITA 2030’s rolling strategic action plan (RSAP), 2018–2020.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The global and regional trade landscape is rapidly evolving with the recent revival of global 
trade and the changing circumstances in the CAREC region. Excluding data from the People’s 
Republic  of  China  (PRC),  CAREC  members  trade  performance  rebounded  from  tepid 
performance in 2016, with merchandise trade expanding 12.8% and commercial trade in services 
increasing 7.3% in 2017. However, the escalation of international trade conflict in 2018 and policy 
uncertainties could undermine the recent trends. Furthermore, the global trade share of CAREC 
members plateaued at less than 1% (excluding the PRC, which accounted for 11.5%) during 
2009–2017.7 Exports from Central Asia show high product concentration and divergence from the 
global pattern. Compared with other regions in Asia and the Pacific, CAREC members are the 
least integrated regionally in terms of trade, investment, and movement of people.8 
 
4.  The importance of trade for CAREC countries cannot be emphasized enough; goods and 
services trade made up 42.5% of CAREC countries’ (excluding the PRC) gross domestic product 
in 2016, lower than the average of 55.4% during 2010–2015. CAREC recognizes the importance 
of simplifying and liberalizing national trade regimes, including through World Trade Organization 
(WTO) membership, to expand trade and improve the investment climate. However, the potential 
to increase trade within CAREC is limited by high trade costs and delays at and behind the borders. 
For instance, border compliance procedures result in an average time to import of 53 hours and 
an average time to export of 58 hours.9 Better implementation of the WTO Trade Facilitation 
                                                
1  ADB. 2018. CAREC Integrated Trade Agenda 2030 and Rolling Strategic Action Plan, 2018–2020. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2017. CAREC 2030: Connecting the Region for Shared and Sustainable Development. Manila. 
3  United Nations. 2015. Transforming Our World: The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. New York. 
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
5  ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020: Promoting Connectivity, 
Competitiveness, Regional Public Goods, and Collective Action for Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
6  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 27 November 2018. 
7  World Trade Organization (WTO). WTO Data portal. http://data.wto.org (accessed 13 September 2018). 
8  ADB. 2017. Asian Economic Integration Report 2017: The Era of Financial Interconnectedness—How Can Asia 
Strengthen Financial Resilience? Manila. 
9 World Economic Forum and the Global Alliance for Trade Facilitation. 2016. The Global Enabling Trade Report 2016. 
Geneva.

2 
Agreement  (TFA)  and  other  trade  facilitation  measures,  such  as  transit  arrangements  for 
landlocked countries, could promote trade expansion. 
 
5.  Most  CAREC  countries  continue  to  rely  heavily  on  primary  and  resource-intensive 
commodities for export, which affects their participation in global and regional value chains. 
Regulatory and institutional reforms are needed to attract investments and expand services trade, 
as inconsistent and restrictive foreign direct investment policies make it difficult to realize the 
potential for cross-border investment facilitation. Meanwhile, the services sector, including air 
passenger transport, auditing, banking, insurance, and communication and professional services, 
remains highly restrictive in most CAREC countries.10 There is a need to create a more favorable 
business environment including adoption of innovative measures and improve export capacity 
and  participation  in  the  supply  chain  by  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  and  female 
entrepreneurs, including their access to trade finance.  
 
6.  Underpinning effective implementation of trade strategies and reforms is the quality of 
institutions  and  regulatory  governance.  However,  CAREC  trade  institutions  face  ineffective 
mechanisms, uncoordinated national and regional planning, and regulatory fragmentation. There 
is also a dearth of up-to-date and relevant information, appropriate skills, and knowledge of 
emerging trade issues for government officials to (i) assess and design policies and (ii) arrive at 
informed decisions to amend or replace outdated trade-related legislations. 
 
7.  Since its inception, CAREC has contributed to building mutual trust and advancing 
regional cooperation, and has recorded successes with knowledge and institution building in the 
trade sector. However, progress among CAREC members has been uneven. The remaining 
challenges include limited outcomes, inadequate investment planning in trade facilitation, lack of 
flagship projects for knowledge support and actionable policy recommendations in trade policy, 
lukewarm country ownership, and shortcomings in coordination and overlapping issues in trade.11 
 
8.  As envisaged in CAREC 2030, a coherent approach to trade through the development of 
a forward-looking regional trade strategy is needed. Among CAREC 2030’s five operational 
clusters,12 the trade, tourism, and economic corridors cluster includes support for WTO accession 
and post-accession, TFA implementation, deepened customs cooperation, and integrated trade 
facilitation. Trade-related priorities are spread out across all CAREC 2030 operational clusters, 
underscoring the cross-sector linkages, broader scope, and new opportunities in CAREC trade 
work. 
 
9.  CITA  2030  will  be  implemented  in  a  phased  and  pragmatic  approach,  taking  into 
consideration the capacity and varying levels of progress of CAREC countries. There will be 
flexibility in allowing two or more CAREC members to initiate and implement regional projects and 
initiatives agreed by them. A 3-year RSAP translates CITA into practical and implementable 
periodic phases, while annual reviews help maintain the RSAP’s relevance. The RSAP, 2018–
2020 identifies investment projects, policy dialogue and cooperation, and knowledge products 
and services prioritized by CAREC countries for the first 3 years of CITA 2030 implementation. 
 
                                                
10 World  Bank.  Services  Trade  Restrictions  Database.  http://iresearch.worldbank.org/servicetrade  (accessed  16 
September 2018). The database covers Georgia, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Pakistan, the PRC, 
and Uzbekistan. 
11 ADB. 2016. CAREC 2020 Midterm Review. Manila. 
12 The five clusters are (i) economic and financial stability; (ii) trade, tourism, and economic corridors; (iii) infrastructure 
and economic connectivity; (iv) agriculture and water; and (v) human development. The use of information and 
communication technology is a cross-cutting priority of CAREC operations.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: integration of CAREC countries in the global 
economy enhanced (footnote 1). The TA will have the following outcome: policy measures to 
enhance the trade performance of CAREC countries adopted.13 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: Knowledge support on increasing market access provided. Through policy 
advice and capacity building activities, the TA will support CAREC countries in adopting open 
trade policies and deepening customs cooperation. Activities will focus on: (i) WTO accession 
and support for CAREC members in their post-accession commitments; (ii) trade policy review; 
(iii) support for implementation of WTO agreements, such as on sanitary and phytosanitary 
measures,  technical  barriers  to  trade,  and  the  TFA;  and  (iv)  scoping  studies  for  potential 
investment projects to improve border services, establish a new border-crossing point with joint 
customs control, and enhance the transit system in CAREC countries. 
 
12.  Output 2: Policy research on economic diversification produced and disseminated. 
The TA will help create an enabling environment for diversification by supporting policy reforms 
and identifying opportunities to expand CAREC countries’ links to regional and global value chains. 
Areas of policy research work include investment policies and cross-border investment measures; 
expansion of services trade and its support services; and promotion of digital trade, innovation, 
and regional value chain development. Sharing of best practices, including through field visits, 
will be implemented under the TA. 
 
13.  Output  3:  Trade  institutions’  capacity  in  policy  coordination,  analysis,  and 
negotiations strengthened. The TA will improve coordination of sector policies and priorities, 
promote evidence-based policy making, and enhance the capacity of trade-related institutions 
and cross-sector mechanisms such as the WTO national committees on trade facilitation. The TA 
will provide a platform to discuss trade issues in a synergistic manner through the Regional Trade 
Group (RTG) and the Customs Cooperation Committee (CCC). The TA will support activities to 
improve data collection and information sharing among CAREC countries; deepen knowledge 
and  awareness  of  emerging  trade  issues,  including  the  scope  of  trade  agreements;  and 
strengthen  the  participation  of  other  stakeholders  such  as  think  tanks  and  private  sector 
associations in trade policy discussions. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,600,000 equivalent, of which (i) $800,000 equivalent will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund14 and (ii) $800,000 
equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction 
and Regional Cooperation Fund15 and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2.  
 
                                                
13 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
14 Established by ADB. Financing partner: the Government of Japan. 
15 The fund was originally named “People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund” in 
the 2005 Board paper.

4 
15.  The  governments  of  each  CAREC  country  will  provide  in-kind  contributions  for  the 
implementation of TA activities and support in the form of staff time and designated personnel 
who will (i) participate in RTG and CCC meetings and other subgroups as may be established, 
and (ii) provide needed data and timely information. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA. The Public Management, Financial Sector, and Regional 
Cooperation Division of ADB’s East Asia Department will serve as the focal point and supervise 
activities, working closely with the CAREC unit of the Central and West Asia Department, the 
resident missions in CAREC countries, and ADB’s Economic Research and Regional Cooperation 
Department particularly on knowledge products. TA implementation will be coordinated with 
ongoing regional TA,16 the CAREC Institute, the Regional Knowledge Sharing Initiative,17 and 
other development partners to create synergies among regional initiatives. 
 
17.  The TA outcomes will feed into the discussions of the CCC, RTG, and relevant sector 
bodies as may be established under CITA 2030. The TA will provide support to monitor progress 
and update the RSAP annually. It will incorporate lessons learned in past regional TA, such as 
the adoption of the “One ADB” approach and sustained dialogue with countries to establish a link 
between strategy and investment projects.18 The implementation arrangements are summarized 
in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements

Implementing agencies  EAPF will implement the TA in consultation with concerned sector 
divisions and resident missions in CAREC countries. 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB

(32 person-months) 
Individual selection  National expertise (30  $280,331 
person-months)

time) and front-loading ADB-administered funds. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank; CAREC = Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation; EAPF = Public Management, 
Financial Sector, and Regional Cooperation Division of the East Asia Department; TA = technical assistance; WTO = 
World Trade Organization. 
Source: ADB. 
 
                                                
16 ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance for Implementation of Trade Facilitation Initiatives in Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation Program. Manila; ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance for Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation: Working with the Private Sector in Trade Facilitation (Phase 2). Manila; ADB. 2018. Technical 
Assistance for Modernizing Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures to Facilitate Trade. Manila; and ADB. 2018. 
Technical Assistance for Implementing the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 2030 Strategy for 
Sustainable Regional Development. Manila. 
17 The Government of the PRC and ADB established the program in 2012 to facilitate the exchange of development-
related knowledge among ADB’s developing member countries. 
18 ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance Completion Report: Integrated Trade Facilitation Support for Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation. Manila; and ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance Completion Report: Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation: Midterm Review of the Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy and Implementation Action 
Plan. Manila.

5 
18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.19 The TA will require 32 person-months of international and 30 person-months 
of national consultant inputs. ADB will recruit consultants individually and not through a firm 
because (i) the range of required experience, expertise, and specific knowledge or familiarity of 
the CAREC Program and countries for each assignment is unlikely to be available in a single firm; 
(ii) faster mobilization of consultants and resource persons to conduct TA activities is needed; 
and (iii) greater flexibility is needed to engage experts in a broad spectrum of trade-related work. 
The Public Management, Financial Sector, and Regional Cooperation Division of ADB’s East Asia 
Department will manage all individual consultants. Where appropriate, output-based contracts will 
be considered for administrative efficiency and for a simplified disbursement process. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $800,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China 
Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund and (ii) ADB providing the balance not 
exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for Implementing the Integrated Trade 
Agenda in the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board. 
                                                
19 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

 Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Knowledge support on increasing market access provided 
1.1 Provide advisory assistance, including through a paper or advisory note, to CAREC members on WTO 
accession, implementation or ratification of a WTO agreement, or trade policy reviews (Q1 2019–Q1 
2021) 
1.2 Conduct knowledge and capacity building activities on identified priority areas under the WTO TFA (Q1 
2019–Q4 2020) 
1.3 Undertake scoping studies to improve border services, establish a new border-crossing point with joint 
customs control, and enhance the transit system through CATS and ICE (Q1 2019–Q4 2020) 
2.  Policy research on economic diversification produced and disseminated 
2.1 Undertake a review of FDI policy or cross-border investment facilitation measures (Q1–Q4 2019) 
2.2 Undertake a scoping study on improving services trade and strengthening linkages with global and 
regional value chains (Q1 2019–Q2 2020) 
2.3 Prepare a scoping study on the adoption of e-commerce and other innovation measures in trade-related 
services of the government (Q2 2019–Q2 2021) 
2.4 Prepare a paper on the development of regional value chains (Q1 2019–Q1 2021) 
2.5 Disseminate the outcomes of policy research activities at a conference, at seminars or similar forums, 
and uploading in the relevant websites (Q2 2019–Q2 2021) 
3.  Trade institutions’ capacity in policy coordination, analysis, and negotiations strengthened

8  Appendix 1 
3.1 Organize cross-learning and capacity building activities for NCTFs or similar mechanisms (Q1 2019–
Q1 2021) 
3.2 Develop an online repository of trade-related information, regulation, and best practices in CAREC 
countries (Q1 2019–Q4 2020) 
3.3 Support annual meetings of CAREC CCC and RTG, including involving other stakeholders such as the 
private sector and research institutions (Q1 2019–Q1 2021) 
3.4 Organize regional training programs on trade analysis and understanding of the emerging scope of 
FTAs (Q1 2019–Q2 2020)

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation
